CONCEPT.LABEL: Communicative state
CONCEPT.DEF: External state of Agent related to communication with other agents or objects.

SUB_L.label: コミュニケーションに関する状態
SUB_L.def: External state of Agent related to communication with other agents or objects.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Passive com. state
CONCEPT.DEF: Passive communicative state

SUB_L.label: 受動的なコミュニケーションに関する状態
SUB_L.def: Passive communicative state

SUB_L.label: 連続的受動的なコミュニケーションに関する状態
結果的受動的なコミュニケーションに関する状態

CONCEPT.LABEL: Have been received
CONCEPT.DEF: State where information has been received.

SUB_L.label: 伝えられた
SUB_L.def: State where information has been received.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Have been directed
CONCEPT.DEF: This state means that information is informed with some intention. This also means that some actions are required after an agent is in this state.

SUB_L.label: 指示された
SUB_L.def: This state means that information is informed with some intention. This also means that some actions are required after an agent is in this state.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Have been requested
CONCEPT.DEF: This state means that an agent who have this are required to do some physical action.

SUB_L.label: 要求された
SUB_L.def: This state means that an agent who have this are required to do some physical action.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Have been let
CONCEPT.DEF: This state means that an agent who have this are required to do some cognitive action.

SUB_L.label: 行為をさせられた
SUB_L.def: This state means that an agent who have this are required to do some cognitive action.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Have been let as a group

SUB_L.label: グループとして実行させた

CONCEPT.LABEL: Have been let as an individual

SUB_L.label: 個人として実行させた

CONCEPT.LABEL: Have been transmitted
CONCEPT.DEF: This state means that information is just informed with no other intention. This also means that no following actions are required.

SUB_L.label: copy : 伝えられた
SUB_L.def: This state means that information is just informed with no other intention. This also means that no following actions are required.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Passive Physical subject state action
CONCEPT.DEF: Actions which change doer's state in a passive way.

SUB_L.label: 受動的動作主物理状態行為
SUB_L.def: Actions which change doer's state in a passive way.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Active Physical subject state action
CONCEPT.DEF: Actions which change doer's state in an active manner.

SUB_L.label: 能動的動作主物理状態行為
SUB_L.def: Actions which change doer's state in an active manner.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Active com. state
CONCEPT.DEF: Active communicative state

SUB_L.label: 能動的なコミュニケーションに関する状態
SUB_L.def: Active communicative state

CONCEPT.LABEL: Continuous active com. state
CONCEPT.DEF: Communicative states sustained for a while.

SUB_L.label: 連続的能動的なコミュニケーションに関する状態
SUB_L.def: Communicative states sustained for a while.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Resultant active com. state
CONCEPT.DEF: Communicative states focused on the resulting state.

SUB_L.label: 結果的能動的なコミュニケーションに関する状態
SUB_L.def: Communicative states focused on the resulting state.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Have performed
CONCEPT.DEF: This concepts was defined in OMNIBUS as Physical state. However, this concepts must be part of Resultatn active com. state to as result of the action perform

認知スキルに関する状態１

CONCEPT.LABEL: Perception level
CONCEPT.DEF:
The ability to use sensory cues to guide motor activity. This ranges from sensory stimulation, through cue selection, to translation.
Simpson E. J. (1972). The Classification of Educational Objectives in the Psychomotor Domain. Washington, DC: Gryphon House.

SUB_L.def: The ability to use sensory cues to guide motor activity. This ranges from sensory stimulation, through cue selection, to translation. Simpson E. J. (1972). The Classification of Educational Objectives in the Psychomotor Domain. Washington, DC: Gryphon House.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Set level
CONCEPT.DEF:
Readiness to act. It includes mental, physical, and emotional sets. These three sets are dispositions that predetermine a person's response to different situations (sometimes called mindsets).
Simpson E. J. (1972). The Classification of Educational Objectives in the Psychomotor Domain. Washington, DC: Gryphon House.

SUB_L.def: Readiness to act. It includes mental, physical, and emotional sets. These three sets are dispositions that predetermine a person's response to different situations (sometimes called mindsets). Simpson E. J. (1972). The Classification of Educational Objectives in the Psychomotor Domain. Washington, DC: Gryphon House.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Guided Response level
CONCEPT.DEF:
The early stages in learning a complex skill that includes imitation and trial and error. Adequacy of performance is achieved by practicing.
Simpson E. J. (1972). The Classification of Educational Objectives in the Psychomotor Domain. Washington, DC: Gryphon House.

SUB_L.def: The early stages in learning a complex skill that includes imitation and trial and error. Adequacy of performance is achieved by practicing. Simpson E. J. (1972). The Classification of Educational Objectives in the Psychomotor Domain. Washington, DC: Gryphon House.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Mechanism level
CONCEPT.DEF:
This is the intermediate stage in learning a complex skill. Learned responses have become habitual and the movements can be performed with some confidence and proficiency.
Simpson E. J. (1972). The Classification of Educational Objectives in the Psychomotor Domain. Washington, DC: Gryphon House.

SUB_L.def: This is the intermediate stage in learning a complex skill. Learned responses have become habitual and the movements can be performed with some confidence and proficiency. Simpson E. J. (1972). The Classification of Educational Objectives in the Psychomotor Domain. Washington, DC: Gryphon House.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Complex Overt Response level
CONCEPT.DEF:
The skillful performance of motor acts that involve complex movement patterns. Proficiency is indicated by a quick, accurate, and highly coordinated performance, requiring a minimum of energy. This category includes performing without hesitation, and automatic performance. For example, players are often utter sounds of satisfaction or expletives as soon as they hit a tennis ball or throw a football, because they can tell by the feel of the act what the result will produce.
Simpson E. J. (1972). The Classification of Educational Objectives in the Psychomotor Domain. Washington, DC: Gryphon House.

SUB_L.def: The skillful performance of motor acts that involve complex movement patterns. Proficiency is indicated by a quick, accurate, and highly coordinated performance, requiring a minimum of energy. This category includes performing without hesitation, and automatic performance. For example, players are often utter sounds of satisfaction or expletives as soon as they hit a tennis ball or throw a football, because they can tell by the feel of the act what the result will produce. Simpson E. J. (1972). The Classification of Educational Objectives in the Psychomotor Domain. Washington, DC: Gryphon House.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Adaptation level
CONCEPT.DEF:
Skills are well developed and the individual can modify movement patterns to fit special requirements.
Simpson E. J. (1972). The Classification of Educational Objectives in the Psychomotor Domain. Washington, DC: Gryphon House.

SUB_L.def: Skills are well developed and the individual can modify movement patterns to fit special requirements. Simpson E. J. (1972). The Classification of Educational Objectives in the Psychomotor Domain. Washington, DC: Gryphon House.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Origination level
CONCEPT.DEF:
Creating new movement patterns to fit a particular situation or specific problem. Learning outcomes emphasize creativity based upon highly developed skills.
Simpson E. J. (1972). The Classification of Educational Objectives in the Psychomotor Domain. Washington, DC: Gryphon House.

SUB_L.label: Origination
SUB_L.def: Creating new movement patterns to fit a particular situation or specific problem. Learning outcomes emphasize creativity based upon highly developed skills. Simpson E. J. (1972). The Classification of Educational Objectives in the Psychomotor Domain. Washington, DC: Gryphon House.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Tune
CONCEPT.DEF:
Rumelhart and Norman (1978, 1981) have proposed three learning processes to account for human reasoning based on schema modification:
tuning (an existing schema has to be slightly changed in order to understand a new concept, e.g. a schema for car may be modified to include a new property . engine_power . or to modify the value of an existing property . number_passengers are less than 6), and
PiagetのAccommodationと同様と思われる

SUB_L.label: 調整して適用する
SUB_L.def: Rumelhart and Norman (1978, 1981) have proposed three learning processes to account for human reasoning based on schema modification: tuning (an existing schema has to be slightly changed in order to understand a new concept, e.g. a schema for car may be modified to include a new property . engine_power . or to modify the value of an existing property . number_passengers are less than 6), and PiagetのAccommodationと同様と思われる

CONCEPT.LABEL: Accrete
CONCEPT.DEF:
Rumelhart and Norman (1978, 1981) have proposed three learning processes to account for human reasoning based on schema modification: accretion (an existing schema from the prior knowledge is directly used to interpret a new concept, e.g. Mercedes can be considered as another example of a car, i.e. the schema of car is instantiated to understand Mercedes),
Similar to Piaget's assimilation

SUB_L.label: そのまま適用する
SUB_L.def: Rumelhart and Norman (1978, 1981) have proposed three learning processes to account for human reasoning based on schema modification: accretion (an existing schema from the prior knowledge is directly used to interpret a new concept, e.g. Mercedes can be considered as another example of a car, i.e. the schema of car is instantiated to understand Mercedes), Similar to Piaget's assimilation

CONCEPT.LABEL: Construction mechanism
CONCEPT.DEF: There is no "internal" model like behaviorism and cognitivism in constructivism because they don't try to explain what happening in the mind. Therefore, what we can have is "external" model like this which is composed of interactive event in an authentic context. Knowledge is built through the interaction.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Constructivism learning
CONCEPT.DEF: It is characterized by learning outcome and learning model. The idea of its learning is "Meaning creation" after learning on the basis of Constructivism model as the Knowledge model.

SUB_L.label: Constructivism model:slot2
SUB_L.class_const: 知識モデルに関する属性

SUB_L.label: 構成主義学習
SUB_L.def: It is characterized by learning outcome and learning model. The idea of its learning is "Meaning creation" after learning on the basis of Constructivism model as the Knowledge model.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Socio-constructivism learning
CONCEPT.DEF:
Its essential property is still on its knowledge model, that is, knowledge is built(meaning is created) by learners.
Another critical property is sociality(socialness), that is, the idea of knowledge exists in a society and learners moves from peripheral to central as learning proceeds.

SUB_L.label: 社会的構成主義学習
SUB_L.def: Its essential property is still on its knowledge model, that is, knowledge is built(meaning is created) by learners. Another critical property is sociality(socialness), that is, the idea of knowledge exists in a society and learners moves from peripheral to central as learning proceeds.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Cognitivism learning
CONCEPT.DEF: It is characterized as the change of the knowledge state and the state after learning is expected better than that of before. Its Knowledge model is based on Cognitive model.

SUB_L.label: Cognitive model:slot2
SUB_L.class_const: 知識モデルに関する属性

SUB_L.label: 認知主義的学習
SUB_L.def: It is characterized as the change of the knowledge state and the state after learning is expected better than that of before. Its Knowledge model is based on Cognitive model.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Behaviorism learning
CONCEPT.DEF: It is characterized by the increase of the performance of the learning outcome.

SUB_L.def: It is characterized by the increase of the performance of the learning outcome.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Stimulus-response model
CONCEPT.DEF: Its style is Performance-based, its framework is Black-box model and its mechanism is Association mechanism.

SUB_L.def: Its style is Performance-based, its framework is Black-box model and its mechanism is Association mechanism.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Cognitive model
CONCEPT.DEF: Its Style is Knowledge-based, its framework is Information processing model, and its mechanism is Cognitive mechanism.

SUB_L.def: Its Style is Knowledge-based, its framework is Information processing model, and its mechanism is Cognitive mechanism.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Constructivism model
CONCEPT.DEF: Its Style is also Knowledge-based which is the same as Cognitive model, its framework is Knowledge building model, and its mechanism is Constructivism mechanism.

SUB_L.label: copy : Constructivism learning
SUB_L.def: Its Style is also Knowledge-based which is the same as Cognitive model, its framework is Knowledge building model, and its mechanism is Constructivism mechanism.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Socio-constructivism model
CONCEPT.DEF: As a computational model, the major difference between socio- and non-socio is its interactive event learners are involved in. In Socio- case, it is social events in which learners are requested to participate.

SUB_L.label: 社会的構成主義学習モデル
SUB_L.def: As a computational model, the major difference between socio- and non-socio is its interactive event learners are involved in. In Socio- case, it is social events in which learners are requested to participate.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Instructional goal
CONCEPT.DEF: Instruction can have two kinds of goals: assess or foster

SUB_L.label: 教授目標
SUB_L.def: Instruction can have two kinds of goals: assess or foster

CONCEPT.LABEL: Instruction
CONCEPT.DEF:
Instruction is an action taken by an instructor (role) to foster or assess learning, through an instructional event and using instructional tools, and supported (+ or less) by principles (from theories).
Why the class Instruction has no sub-classes is because: 1) it is defined as a generic entity like Learning in the LW 2) Instructional strategies are defined under Instructional process 3) Concrete versions of Instructional strategies are defined as Ways of instructing are called Educational strategies, to be found in the relational concept pane.

SUB_L.label: copy : Learning
SUB_L.def: This is desinged intended to have a common framework for learning models. It is characterized by learners, what learning outcome is expected, what learning events are expected, what knowledge models are assumed, and what learning goals are expected. The last might be unnecessary in this level of abstraction.

CONCEPT.DEF: Instructional entity contains Instructional process (strategies) and Instructional tools (objects)

SUB_L.def: Instructional entity contains Instructional process (strategies) and Instructional tools (objects)

CONCEPT.LABEL: Macro strategy type
CONCEPT.DEF:
Macro strategies are concerned with the selection, sequence, and organization(structure) of the subject-matter topics that are to be presented.
From M. D. Merrill: Component Display Theory, In Reigeluth, C. M. (Ed.), Instructional-design theories and models: An overview of their current status. Hillsdale, New Jersey: Lawrence Erlbaum Associates, Inc., pp. 279-334, 1983.
This is from Reigeluth, C. M., Merrill, M. D.: A Knowledge Base for Improving Our Methods of Instruction, Educational Psychologist, 13, p. 57-70, 1978.

SUB_L.def: Macro strategies are concerned with the selection, sequence, and organization(structure) of the subject-matter topics that are to be presented. From M. D. Merrill: Component Display Theory, In Reigeluth, C. M. (Ed.), Instructional-design theories and models: An overview of their current status. Hillsdale, New Jersey: Lawrence Erlbaum Associates, Inc., pp. 279-334, 1983. This is from Reigeluth, C. M., Merrill, M. D.: A Knowledge Base for Improving Our Methods of Instruction, Educational Psychologist, 13, p. 57-70, 1978.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Micro strategy type
CONCEPT.DEF:
Micro strategies are concerned with the individual displays --- including their characteristics, interrelationships, and sequence --- that are to be presented to the student. Micro strategies also be characterized as presentation strategies because they are concerned with the details of each individual presentation to the student.
From M. D. Merrill: Component Display Theory, In Reigeluth, C. M. (Ed.), Instructional-design theories and models: An overview of their current status. Hillsdale, New Jersey: Lawrence Erlbaum Associates, Inc., pp. 279-334, 1983.
This is from Reigeluth, C. M., Merrill, M. D.: A Knowledge Base for Improving Our Methods of Instruction, Educational Psychologist, 13, p. 57-70, 1978.

SUB_L.def: Micro strategies are concerned with the individual displays --- including their characteristics, interrelationships, and sequence --- that are to be presented to the student. Micro strategies also be characterized as presentation strategies because they are concerned with the details of each individual presentation to the student. From M. D. Merrill: Component Display Theory, In Reigeluth, C. M. (Ed.), Instructional-design theories and models: An overview of their current status. Hillsdale, New Jersey: Lawrence Erlbaum Associates, Inc., pp. 279-334, 1983. This is from Reigeluth, C. M., Merrill, M. D.: A Knowledge Base for Improving Our Methods of Instruction, Educational Psychologist, 13, p. 57-70, 1978.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Delivery strategy type
CONCEPT.DEF:
Delivery strategies are those decisions affecting the way the information will be carried to the student. Delivery strategies affect the selection of the instructional media that will be used to present the learning activities.
From M. D. Merrill: Component Display Theory, In Reigeluth, C. M. (Ed.), Instructional-design theories and models: An overview of their current status. Hillsdale, New Jersey: Lawrence Erlbaum Associates, Inc., pp. 279-334, 1983.
This is from Reigeluth, C. M., Merrill, M. D.: A Knowledge Base for Improving Our Methods of Instruction, Educational Psychologist, 13, p. 57-70, 1978.

SUB_L.def: Delivery strategies are those decisions affecting the way the information will be carried to the student. Delivery strategies affect the selection of the instructional media that will be used to present the learning activities. From M. D. Merrill: Component Display Theory, In Reigeluth, C. M. (Ed.), Instructional-design theories and models: An overview of their current status. Hillsdale, New Jersey: Lawrence Erlbaum Associates, Inc., pp. 279-334, 1983. This is from Reigeluth, C. M., Merrill, M. D.: A Knowledge Base for Improving Our Methods of Instruction, Educational Psychologist, 13, p. 57-70, 1978.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Management strategy type
CONCEPT.DEF:
Management strategies are those decisions affecting the way the individual student will be helped to interact with learning activities. Management strategies involve motivational techniques, individualization schemes, scheduling, resource allocation, and other implementation activities.
From M. D. Merrill: Component Display Theory, In Reigeluth, C. M. (Ed.), Instructional-design theories and models: An overview of their current status. Hillsdale, New Jersey: Lawrence Erlbaum Associates, Inc., pp. 279-334, 1983.
This is from Reigeluth, C. M., Merrill, M. D.: A Knowledge Base for Improving Our Methods of Instruction, Educational Psychologist, 13, p. 57-70, 1978.

SUB_L.def: Management strategies are those decisions affecting the way the individual student will be helped to interact with learning activities. Management strategies involve motivational techniques, individualization schemes, scheduling, resource allocation, and other implementation activities. From M. D. Merrill: Component Display Theory, In Reigeluth, C. M. (Ed.), Instructional-design theories and models: An overview of their current status. Hillsdale, New Jersey: Lawrence Erlbaum Associates, Inc., pp. 279-334, 1983. This is from Reigeluth, C. M., Merrill, M. D.: A Knowledge Base for Improving Our Methods of Instruction, Educational Psychologist, 13, p. 57-70, 1978.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Theory
CONCEPT.DEF:
a theory is 'a a conceptual system that: - describes a phenomenon - explains it (hypothesis or proof) - provides laws or principles -provides taxonomies - provide methodologies - can allow predictions
-is refutable. Refutable means that the conceptual system to explain the phenomena, together with either the hypothesis or the proof, is clearly exposed and documented with a rationale, a critique of previous or other current theories, has a clear argumentation, clear methodology, etc... so that it can be refuted. It a characteristic of science, and theory belongs to the world of science.

SLOT.DEF: learning is a function of change in overt behavior. Changes in behavior are the result of an individual's response to events (stimuli) that occur in the environment. A response produces a consequence such as defining a word, hitting a ball, or solving a math problem. When a particular Stimulus-Response (S-R) pattern is reinforced (rewarded), the individual is conditioned to respond

SLOT.DEF: Cognitive structures change through the processes of adaptation: assimilation and accommodation. CONCEPT.LABEL: Positive interdependence
CONCEPT.DEF:
http://www.intime.uni.edu/coop_learning/ch4/default.htm
“Positive interdependence is linking students together so one cannot succeed unless all group members succeed. Group members have to know that they sink or swim together.” (Johnson, Johnson, & Holubec, 1998, p. 4:7).
“When students clearly understand positive interdependence, they understand that each group member’s efforts are required and indispensable for group success and that each group member has a unique contribution to make to the joint effort because of his or her resources and/or role and task responsibilities” (Johnson, Johnson, & Holubec 1998).
Positive goal interdependence ensures that the group is united around a common goal, a concrete reason for being, such as “learning the assigned material and making sure that all other members of your group learn the assigned material” (Johnson, Johnson and Holubec, 1998, p. 4:8).
Johnson, D., Johnson, R.& Holubec, E. (1998). Cooperation in the classroom. Boston: Allyn and Bacon.

SUB_L.def: http://www.intime.uni.edu/coop_learning/ch4/default.htm “Positive interdependence is linking students together so one cannot succeed unless all group members succeed. Group members have to know that they sink or swim together.” (Johnson, Johnson, & Holubec, 1998, p. 4:7). “When students clearly understand positive interdependence, they understand that each group member’s efforts are required and indispensable for group success and that each group member has a unique contribution to make to the joint effort because of his or her resources and/or role and task responsibilities” (Johnson, Johnson, & Holubec 1998). Positive goal interdependence ensures that the group is united around a common goal, a concrete reason for being, such as “learning the assigned material and making sure that all other members of your group learn the assigned material” (Johnson, Johnson and Holubec, 1998, p. 4:8). Johnson, D., Johnson, R.& Holubec, E. (1998). Cooperation in the classroom. Boston: Allyn and Bacon.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Individual accountability
CONCEPT.DEF:
http://www.intime.uni.edu/coop_learning/ch4/default.htm
“Individual accountability is the measurement of whether or not each group member has achieved the groups’ goal. Assessing the quality and quantity of each member’s contributions and giving the results to all group members” (Johnson, Johnson, & Holubec, 1998).
Individual accountability is the factor that shows that students are learning better cooperatively. “The purpose of cooperative groups is to make each member a stronger individual in his or her own right” (Johnson, Johnson, & Holubec, 1998, p. 4:17). After participating in a cooperative lesson, group members should be better able to accomplish the same kind of tasks by themselves. They learn to do something together so that they can do it easier when they are alone.
There are many ways to structure and increase individual accountability: by keeping the size of the groups small; by giving an individual test to each student; or by checking for understanding by giving random oral individual examinations. When students have to provide information in the presence of the group, the teacher can also structure individual accountability by observing each group and group member and by keeping track of students’ contribution to the group’s work. Individual accountability can be structured by assigning one student in each group to check for understanding. The checker poses questions, and the other group members provide rational answers supporting group answers. Students can also teach what they have learned to someone else or edit each other’s work (Johnson, Johnson, & Holubec 1998).
Reference
Johnson, D., Johnson, R.& Holubec, E. (1998). Cooperation in the classroom. Boston: Allyn and Bacon.

SUB_L.def: http://www.intime.uni.edu/coop_learning/ch4/default.htm “Individual accountability is the measurement of whether or not each group member has achieved the groups’ goal. Cooperation in the classroom. Boston: Allyn and Bacon.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Promotive interactions
CONCEPT.DEF:
http://www.wcer.wisc.edu/archive/Cl1/CL/moreinfo/MI3C.htm
promotive interactions give individuals opportunities to help each other overcome problems. They provide the feedback between members necessary for all individuals to test ideas and build a framework for their knowledge, and they provide resource sharing. Finally, they embody respect, caring, and encouragement between individuals so all are motivated to continue to work on the task at hand.
Cooper, J., Prescott, S., Cook, L., Smith, L., Mueck, R., and Cuseo, J. (1990). Cooperative learning and college instruction: Effective use of student learning teams. California State University Foundation, Long Beach, CA.
Johnson, D. W., Johnson, R. T. (1987). Learning Together & Alone, Cooperative, Competitive, & Individualistic Learning. 2nd ed., Englewood Cliffs, NJ: Prentice Hall.
Johnson, D. W., Johnson, R. T., and Smith, K. A. (1998). Active learning: Cooperation in the college classroom. Edina, MN: Interaction Book Company.
Smith, K. A. (1996). "Cooperative Learning: Making 'Group work' Work" In Sutherland, T. E., and Bonwell, C. C. (Eds.), Using active learning in college classes: A range of options for faculty, New Directions for Teaching and Learning No. 67.

SLOT.label: slot2
SLOT.DEF: Learning styles are often confused with learning strategies, yet they are quite different concepts. Learning strategies are the particular techniques or methods students use in learning situations to solve problems, approach an assignment, prepare for a test, or otherwise engage in classroom activities. These strategies can be learned, and students can consciously choose to apply one or another learning strategy to a given learning situation (Wenden, 1985; Oxford, 1990). Learning styles, on the other hand, are a part of an individual’s makeup or personality. While an individual may prefer one type of learning style over another for different kinds of learning tasks, the fact remains that a learning style preference reflects an individual’s own personal predilection for how to learn in a particular situation. As people’s personalities change over time, so too can their learning style preferences; such changes in preferences occur over time and generally as a result of exposure to different teaching/learning situations. (A.C. Wintergerst et al. / System 31 (2003) 85-106)

SUB_L.label: slot2

Learning styles, on the other hand, are a part of an individual’s makeup or personality. While an individual may prefer one type of learning style over another for different kinds of learning tasks, the fact remains that a learning style preference reflects an individual’s own personal predilection for how to learn in a particular situation. As people’s personalities change over time, so too can their learning style preferences; such changes in preferences occur over time and generally as a result of exposure to different teaching/learning situations. (A.C. Wintergerst et al. / System 31 (2003) 85-106)

CONCEPT.LABEL: Individual personality preference
CONCEPT.DEF:
This class containts the preference scales that are used in a wide variety of theories to develo model of personality traits.
In general, each individual personality preference is indicated by strength of score in different personality test (that can use their proper scale).

CONCEPT.LABEL: Playing style
CONCEPT.DEF: Dimension that indicates the preferences of a person who is playing a game

CONCEPT.LABEL: Interacting-orientation
CONCEPT.DEF: Bidirectional preference of an individual to act with something and likes with acceptance the acts from this something

CONCEPT.LABEL: Acting-orientation
CONCEPT.DEF: One directional preference of an individual to act with something

SLOT.label: slot3
SLOT.role: Theory of motivation and human behavior

CONCEPT.LABEL: Game component
CONCEPT.DEF: These elements are the tangible forms of mechanics and dynamics

CONCEPT.LABEL: Game dynamic
CONCEPT.DEF: These game elements are the highest level of abstraction in a gamified system and containts some of the fundamental aspects of gamification

CONCEPT.LABEL: Game event
CONCEPT.DEF: . Finally, the game event was defined by game design theories.

SLOT.label: slot3
SLOT.class_constraint: Game design theory | Game design model

SUB_L.class_const: Game design theory | Game design model

CONCEPT.LABEL: Non-game event
CONCEPT.DEF:
ordinary event_2 are ordinary events that are not classified as extrinsic or intrinsic accomplishment in our ontology. The purpose of this concepts is to define a bring among the other classifications (such as educational events - OMNIBUS) that were done in previous papers.
We define this concept because the Hozo editor (in the 5.5 beta version) doesn't save weak IS-A relation from an imported concept of other ontology.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Achievement system
CONCEPT.DEF: (TODO): For the complete formalization of this component, it is necessary to see: - Hamari, J., & Eranti, V. (2011). Framework for designing and evaluating game achievements. Proc. DiGRA 2011: Think Design Play, 115(115), 122-134. - http://www.slideshare.net/Leyart1/achievement-systems-explained

CONCEPT.LABEL: Game constraints
CONCEPT.DEF: Limitations impose to force the trade-off in the games

CONCEPT.LABEL: Game emotions
CONCEPT.DEF: Affective states (more specifically emotions) that will be obtained in the games. e.g. happy, competitive, frustrated

CONCEPT.LABEL: Game narratives
CONCEPT.DEF: The storylines or coherent whole of the game (ongoing storyline).

CONCEPT.LABEL: Game progressions
CONCEPT.DEF: The improvement of players in the game. Progression about the player’s growth and development.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Game relationships
CONCEPT.DEF:
The kind of interactions with other players. The social interactions that generate feelings of camaraderie, status, altruism, and so on.
Teammates, opponents, friends, etc.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Game mechanics
CONCEPT.DEF:
The game mechanics are processes (actions/behavior/motion) in the game that move the system forward and generate player engagement. Theses processes are classified in different groups as challenges, chance, competition, cooperation, feedback, ...
These elements help to determine how to engage players into the game and move the action forward. The mechanics are used to achieve the elements from the dynamics because they stimulate the behavior of the player in the desirable direction.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Mastermind role
CONCEPT.DEF: BrainHex is related to Achievement-Mechanics motivation (in Yee' model), and is partly related to the Explorer role (in Bartle's model).

CONCEPT.LABEL: BrainHex's achiever role
CONCEPT.DEF: It is related to the Achiever role (in Bartle's model), and the Achievement-Advancement and Immersion-Discovery motivations in (Yee's model)

SLOT.label: slot5
SLOT.DEF: This is related to achievement-advancement and immersion-discovery motivations

CONCEPT.LABEL: Conqueror role
CONCEPT.DEF: It is related to Achievement-Competition motivation (in Yee's model), and partly related to the Killer role and Achiever roles (in Bartle's model)

CONCEPT.LABEL: Seeker role
CONCEPT.DEF: It is related to Immersion motivation (in Yee's model), and is partly related to the Explorer role (in Bartle's model)

CONCEPT.LABEL: Survivor role
CONCEPT.DEF: It is related to Immersion-Escapism motivation (in Yee's model)

CONCEPT.LABEL: BrainHex's socializer role
CONCEPT.DEF: It is related to Social motivation (in Yee's model) and Socialiser role (in Bartle's model)

CONCEPT.LABEL: Daredevil role
CONCEPT.DEF: It is possibly being related to Immersion-Escapism motivation (in Yee's model)

SLOT.label: slot5
SLOT.DEF: This is probably relation non necessary!!

CONCEPT.LABEL: 8-BrainHex player roles
CONCEPT.DEF:
Classification based on yee's motivational components, myers-briggs type indicator and bartle's model.
For more information, see: - Nacke, L. E., Bateman, C., & Mandryk, R. L. (2014). BrainHex: A neurobiological gamer typology survey. Entertainment computing, 5(1), 55-62 (Relationships with motivational components are necessary conditions). - Paulin, R. E., Battaiola, A. L., & Alves, M. M. (2014). The Study of the Relations between the BrainHex Player Profiles, MBTI Psychological Types and Emotions as Means to Enhance User Experience (pp. 732-741). Springer. (factors of primary MBTI psychological types with more percentual of correspondency are consider desired condition)

CONCEPT.LABEL: Cognitive learning style
CONCEPT.DEF:
Dimension that indicate the preference during the cognitive learning. Each is not a polar opposite, but a gradual continuum preference.
See more in: Briggs, K. C. (1976). Myers-Briggs type indicator. Palo Alto, CA: Consulting Psychologists Press.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Communal discovery
CONCEPT.DEF: Community has to work together to overcome obstacle, individual effort is undermined. This a common feature used in different games to create special dynamics and mechanics that shared virtual items.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Gamified demonstrating how to solve a problem
Gamified notifying how the learner is
Gamified setting up learning context type CA
Gamified showing a solution type CA
Game feature
CONCEPT.DEF: The game features are frequently confused by many practitioners and some researchers as game mechanics, game dynamics or game components in differents frameworks/models. To avoid this confusion, in our ontology, we make a clearly differenciation of these concepts. For more details, see the paper:

CONCEPT.LABEL: Levels
CONCEPT.DEF: Players receive points for actions, can level up, and gain new abilities. The levels can be used to divide the intended learning behavior defined in the systems in different levels.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Pride
CONCEPT.DEF: Feeling of joy and ownership after accomplishment. A game provides in general this feature for their users employing virtual items as (badges, trophes and others shareable items as rankings)

CONCEPT.LABEL: Social fabric of games
CONCEPT.DEF: People grow closer after playing together, people playing together to make friends. The purpose of the game is find a way to increase the communication and cooperation between players.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Viral game mechanics
CONCEPT.DEF: Games are more enjoyable with this feature in which some elements are only accessible with others, will make people want to cooperate.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Status
CONCEPT.DEF: Feature that defines rank or level of player

CONCEPT.LABEL: Envy
CONCEPT.DEF: Striving for what other players have to increase competition and comparison. We can use exclusive rewards to provide this feature

CONCEPT.LABEL: Countdown
CONCEPT.DEF: Feature in that the players have a limited amount of time to complete a challenge.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Leaderboards
CONCEPT.DEF: Games with this features use visual displays of players in which the progression and achievements display highscores. The measurement of intended learning behavior can be used to obtain the scores.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Distribute virtual items
CONCEPT.DEF: Distribute virtual items to reward players is a common feature of games that in many cases are perceived as real-money value for the players.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Reward schedules
CONCEPT.DEF: Game's feature in which the virtual items give variable and fixed intervals of rewards

CONCEPT.LABEL: Lottery
CONCEPT.DEF: Feature in which the game gives the players opportunity of winning stuff (using lottery)

CONCEPT.LABEL: Points (pontification)
CONCEPT.DEF: Measurement of success of in-game actions

CONCEPT.LABEL: Bonuses
CONCEPT.DEF: Some games provide extra rewards for overcoming challenges reinforcing the desired behaviour.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Appointments
CONCEPT.DEF: Feature in which the game containts fixed in-game appointments that are employed to make players return at certain locations/times.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Achievements
CONCEPT.DEF: Games that use virtual/physical representation of accomplishment; achievements can be broken and tied to tasks, it can also be projected

CONCEPT.LABEL: Epic meaning
CONCEPT.DEF:
Having something great as background story to give meaning to in-game actions. The story could link behavioural outcomes to player`s actions.
In tailor strategy, the story can be tailored to each player using various characteristics

CONCEPT.LABEL: Behavior momentum
CONCEPT.DEF: The game provides messages and rewards in which the system maintaints the players keep going because they feel what they are doing is valuable

CONCEPT.LABEL: Urgent optimism
CONCEPT.DEF: High self-motivation, players want to work on issues instantly with the belief that they will succeed

CONCEPT.LABEL: Blissful productivity
CONCEPT.DEF: By this feature, the players work hard within game if actions are meaningful

CONCEPT.LABEL: Cascadign information
CONCEPT.DEF: Feature in which gradually the players are introduced to game creating a sense of personal relevance.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Privacity
CONCEPT.DEF: Feature in which certain information is shared, certain information is kept private for the user alone.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Discovery
CONCEPT.DEF: Feature in which the game gives the players opportunity to explore and find new things makes players fill sense of control and autonomy associated with customization

CONCEPT.LABEL: Quests
CONCEPT.DEF: Features in which the games display tasks that players have to complete help the player monitor performance and progress

CONCEPT.LABEL: Loss aversion
CONCEPT.DEF: Game's feature in wich not punishing player as long as the desired behaviour is shown (but not rewarding either)

CONCEPT.LABEL: Repeat simple action
CONCEPT.DEF: The players enjoy repeating simple in-game actions

CONCEPT.LABEL: Game element
CONCEPT.DEF: Classification non defined in (Werbach & Hunter, 2012)

CONCEPT.LABEL: Player role
CONCEPT.DEF: There are the player roles that will be employed to gamify a scenario

CONCEPT.LABEL: Gamifying by persuasive strategy COOP, REWD, SEMT/SUGG

SLOT.label: slot
SLOT.DEF: Based in an agent information

SLOT.label: slot3
SLOT.DEF: Qualifications, Certifications and Licenses (qcl): Qualifications, certifications and licenses granted by recognized authorities;

SLOT.label: slot4
SLOT.DEF: Activity: Any learning-related activity in any state of completion. Could be self-reported. Includes formal and informal education, training, work experience, and military or civic service;

SLOT.label: slot5
SLOT.DEF: Transcript: A record that is used to provide an institutionally-based summary of academic achievement. The structure of this record can take many forms;

CONCEPT.LABEL: gender
CONCEPT.DEF: Categorical attribute assigned by individual or others based on the sex. For now, we only represented basic genders male and female, based in a gender binary system. In anothers cultures, there are more than two genders (e.g. indian hindu, juchitan of mexico). Maybe is better include the alternative model propsed by Fausto-Sterling with five possibilities: male, female, merm, ferm, and herm.

CONCEPT.LABEL: Theory and Model
CONCEPT.DEF: TandM contains the things that are specific to Theories and models. It refers to the things in the worlds of learning, instruction, ID-ISD, and cognition. Theories are structured based on paradigms such as behaviorism etc.

SUB_L.def: TandM contains the things that are specific to Theories and models. It refers to the things in the worlds of learning, instruction, ID-ISD, and cognition. Theories are structured based on paradigms such as behaviorism etc.
